content:
IT lass="word-wrap-span">WAS A staggering reversal. On lass="word-wrap-span">September 20th lass="word-wrap-span">President Joko Widodo, popularly known as Jokowi, lass="word-wrap-span">abruptly asked lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia’s parliament to delay a vote on a new criminal code that has provoked a storm of lass="word-wrap-span">criticism both at home and abroad. lass="word-wrap-span">Among other things the code outlaws lass="word-wrap-span">extramarital sex and same-sex relations, and criminalises lass="word-wrap-span">criticism of the lass="word-wrap-span">President. Jokowi’s request came just two days after his government and the parliament agreed on a final draft of the bill, and four days before legislators were expected to pass it.

lass="word-wrap-span">The proposed revisions to lass="word-wrap-span">The penal code, which dates from lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Dutch lass="word-wrap-span">colonial era, reach deep into lass="word-wrap-span">The private lives of lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesians. lass="word-wrap-span">The bill would punish lass="word-wrap-span">cohabitation and lass="word-wrap-span">consensual sex outside marriage with up to a year in jail. lass="word-wrap-span">Because lass="word-wrap-span">There is no provision for same-sex marriage in lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia, lass="word-wrap-span">The new code in effect bans same-sex relations, too. It punishes some lass="word-wrap-span">abortions with prison terms of four to five years, and lass="word-wrap-span">contrives to lass="word-wrap-span">censor lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">dissemination of information about lass="word-wrap-span">contraception.

In addition to jeopardising lass="word-wrap-span">The rights of women and sexual minorities, lass="word-wrap-span">The bill also lass="word-wrap-span">discriminates against religious minorities. lass="word-wrap-span">Though lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia is a lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim-majority country—lass="word-wrap-span">The world’s largest—it is also home to millions of lass="word-wrap-span">Christians, lass="word-wrap-span">Hindus and lass="word-wrap-span">Buddhists. lass="word-wrap-span">The bill lass="word-wrap-span">endorses “living laws”, by which it means local by-laws, which often reflect a lass="word-wrap-span">chauvinist and puritanical lass="word-wrap-span">interpretation of Islam and are regularly thrown out by lass="word-wrap-span">The government and lass="word-wrap-span">The courts.

lass="word-wrap-span">Pluralism is baked into lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia’s state philosophy. lass="word-wrap-span">Yet in the past few years, religious lass="word-wrap-span">intolerance has been on the rise. lass="word-wrap-span">Conservative Islam has lass="word-wrap-span">emerged as a potent political force. Jokowi, on whom lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesian liberals and secularists pinned great hopes when he first took office in 2014, has been criticised for failing to stand up to this trend. lass="word-wrap-span">During the presidential election in lass="word-wrap-span">April, he picked as his running mate Ma’ruf Amin, a prominent lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">cleric. lass="word-wrap-span">last month the Ulema lass="word-wrap-span">Council, a powerful lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim organisation run by Mr Amin, encouraged Jokowi to lass="word-wrap-span">approve the new criminal code. lass="word-wrap-span">Andreas Harsono, of lass="word-wrap-span">Human lass="word-wrap-span">Rights lass="word-wrap-span">Watch, a lobby group, described the bill as “the lass="word-wrap-span">crown lass="word-wrap-span">jewel of the sharia campaign in lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia”.

lass="word-wrap-span">Civil-rights groups and NGOs have lass="word-wrap-span">denounced the bill. “lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia’s draft lass="word-wrap-span">Criminal code is lass="word-wrap-span">disastrous not only for women and religious and gender minorities, but for all lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesians,” argues Mr Harsono. lass="word-wrap-span">Citing a study indicating that 40% of lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesian lass="word-wrap-span">adolescents have had sex before marriage, the lass="word-wrap-span">Institute for lass="word-wrap-span">Criminal lass="word-wrap-span">Justice lass="word-wrap-span">Reform has cautioned that millions could be penalised.

lass="word-wrap-span">Foreigners would not be lass="word-wrap-span">immune from the new laws—although because only relatives would be allowed to report people for extra-marital sex, prosecutions may in practice be rare. On lass="word-wrap-span">September 20th the lass="word-wrap-span">Australian government updated its travel advice warning citizens about the proposed legal changes. lass="word-wrap-span">More than 1m lass="word-wrap-span">Australians travel to lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesia each year.

At a televised news conference, Jokowi stated that after listening to lass="word-wrap-span">criticisms of rights and civil-society groups, he had concluded that further lass="word-wrap-span">deliberation of the bill was needed. He said that he had directed the minister of law and human rights to tell parliament that the bill’s passage should be postponed until it could be further lass="word-wrap-span">discussed by the next session of parliament, which begins in lass="word-wrap-span">October. “I have also ordered the law and human rights minister to seek inputs from various society groups to perfect the revision,” Jokowi said.

lass="word-wrap-span">Legally, parliament is not bound by the president’s request, but it is very unlikely to ignore it, argues lass="word-wrap-span">Tim lass="word-wrap-span">Lindsey, director of the Centre for lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesian lass="word-wrap-span">Law, Islam and lass="word-wrap-span">Society at lass="word-wrap-span">Melbourne lass="word-wrap-span">University. He told the lass="word-wrap-span">Sydney lass="word-wrap-span">Morning lass="word-wrap-span">Herald , “lass="word-wrap-span">You have to ask why Jokowi agreed to proceed with this lass="word-wrap-span">Law, then reversed his position. lass="word-wrap-span">Either he wasn’t paying attention to the lass="word-wrap-span">Laws, or he came under huge political pressure. lass="word-wrap-span">Maybe he is just lass="word-wrap-span">hugely lass="word-wrap-span">embarrassed by the international media storm.”
